pageData.text: Fungal spores are everywhere. Mold is a common term used to describe fungi that grow multicellular filamentous hyphae. Toxic “black mold” inside buildings can be attributed to various fungal species, but most commonly it is found to be caused by Stachybotrys chartarum. Mold growth in homes can cause mild symptoms such as sore throat, nasal congestion, or coughing. However, people with asthma, those who are immunecompromised, or those who have lung infections can suffer severe symptoms. In this investigation, you will test different common household cleaners, and common products to determine their effectiveness in preventing mold growth.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 60–90 minutes
Activity 1: Cleaning Solution Test Inoculating the PDA Plates – 30 minutes
                 Preparation and Application of Cleaning Solutions – 15–30 minutes
                 Incubation – 24, 48, and 72 hours
Activity 2: Product/Food Fungal Inhibition Test Inoculating the PDA Plates – 30 minutes
                 Preparation and Application of Products or Foods – 15–30 minutes
                 Incubation – 24, 48, and 72 hours

Baking soda (¼ teaspoon)
Vinegar (1 mL)
Dish soap (1 drop)
Bleach (1 mL)
4 household or food products, about 1 mL each (examples include shampoo, mouthwash, toothpaste, hot sauce, or garlic water)
Paper towels
Small plastic container for use as disposal jar (for lab use only)
Large plastic container for disinfecting cultures (for lab use only)
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Timer, stopwatch, or a resealable plastic bag to protect mobile device if using as a timer (optional)
Fine-tip permanent marker (optional)
Dark paper or surface (optional)

text: Test the effectiveness of five common household cleaners in preventing the growth of Rhizopus stolonifera.
Test the effectiveness of four common household products and their ability to prevent the growth of R. stolonifera.
Explain, based on observed results, the advantages of one household cleaner over the other.
Explain which common recommendation for the removal, control, and prevention of regrowth of “black mold” should be used indoors.

pageData.text: Fungi are everywhere. Ancient people have used fungi and bacteria to make fermented beverages, bread, and many other fermented foods for thousands of years. The first record of fermentation was in North Africa over 10,000 years ago when milk from livestock naturally fermented in the warm sun; this is the first known instance of yogurt. Fungi continue to be important in producing food and by-products for human consumption. In addition, many species of fungi produce chemicals that are used in drugs as statins, which control cholesterol levels and ward off coronary heart disease. Fungi are also used in the production of other medicines, several organic acids, biofuels, enzymes, and vitamins. Some fungi can be both harmful and beneficial to humans, and one example finds its way into historical significance in the early United States.

Claviceps purpurea is a medically important sac fungus and is commonly called ergot because it causes a plant disease called ergot. The disease is characterized by a growth that develops on grasses, especially rye. It has been hypothesized that the bread that many of the girls who were accused of being witches during the Salem witch trials had been accidentally poisoned by consuming bread made with flour that was contaminated with ergot. Claviceps purpurea is a source of chemicals used in drugs that induce labor in pregnant women and that control hemorrhage after birth. Claviceps purpurea is also the source of lysergic acid, the active agent in the psychedelic drug lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD).

pageData.altText: A piece of bread covered in dark fuzzy circles of mold.

pageData.text: A fungus (plural, fungi) is a heterotrophic eukaryotic organism that typically absorbs nutrients from the environment, secreting digestive enzymes to break down materials before they are absorbed. According to Hawksworth and Lücking (2017), there have been over 148,000 species of fungi classified, but it has been estimated that only 3 to 8 percent of fungi have been identified and that there are over 2 million species. Currently, there are five true phyla of fungi. (Chytrids) are the simplest fungi, with the majority of them being aquatic. (conjugated fungi) is the smallest group of fungi, and most live off decaying plant materials, although a few species are parasitic. Many (sac fungi) are of commercial importance, ranging from producing food products and pharmaceuticals to being pathogenic to plants and animals. (club fungi) are easily recognizable under a light microscope because of their club-shaped fruiting bodies (basidia), which are the swollen terminal cell of a hypha. The basidia are the reproductive organs of these fungi and are often contained within the familiar mushroom that is commonly thought of when discussing fungi. (mycorrhizae) is a recently described phyla that contain about 230 species that are obligately symbiotic with the roots of plants, forming arbuscular mycorrhizae, which improves plant water and nutrient uptake and provides resistance to several abiotic stress factors.

Although most fungi are not harmful to human health, overexposure can cause complications. Growth of a “black mold” inside buildings can cause illness, especially for at-risk individuals. “Black mold” is a blanket term given to a wide range of fungi that are associated with growing indoors (Stachybotrys spp., Cladosporium spp., Penicillium spp., and Aspergillus spp.). If “black mold” is in an environment, leaving out a piece of bread in a humid location for a couple of days will culture this mold, as well as any other fungi present. The bread mold is commonly caused by the growth of Rhizopus stolonifera, is a nonpathogenic environmental fungus.

pageData.subTitle: Rhizopus sporangia
pageData.text: The mycelium of fungi in the genus Rhizopus is composed of non-septate (undivided), multinucleate hyphae. (Figure 1, letter a) are horizontal hyphae that form a group of (b) when they contact a solid substrate. Rhizoids penetrate the substrate to anchor the fungus. (c) extend above the rhizoids and terminate in a globose (d). The sporangium contains asexual spores, sporangiospores (e), and has an outer (f) and an inner sterile zone. The inner zone is called the (g) and it aids in the release of the spores from the sporangium at maturity. Sexual reproduction in Rhizopus occurs when two hyphae of opposite mating types (+ and –) fuse to form a zygospore. After dormancy, the zygospore undergoes meiosis and germinates to form a germ sporangium. Sporangiospores from this sporangium form new mycelia.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Magnified diagram of Rhizopus sporangia

pageData.text: “Black mold” prefers a humid environment and needs moisture for growth. Often “black mold” is found growing on wood and drywall where water damage, flooding, water leaks, or condensation occurs. “Black mold” can be difficult to remove, control, and prevent regrowth.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A view of fungal growth from the top of a culture dish which shows black spores around the edge of the petri dish

pageData.text: Figure 2 shows an example of R. stolonifera growth after 72 hours. This is a view of the fungal growth from the top. Notice the black spores around the edge of the petri dish. The black sporangia produce numerous multinucleate spores for asexual reproduction and it this characteristic that gives these types of fungi the name “black mold.” Figure 3 shows a culture plate looking at fungal growth from the bottom of the plate.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Culture plate looking at fungal growth from the bottom

pageData.text: A basic internet search on how to remove, control, and prevent the regrowth of “black mold” results in many different recommendations, some of which have proven to be effective, while others have not. You will be testing the following recommendations:

text: Cleaning with soap is a popular suggestion.
A 10% baking soda solution has also been suggested to be effective at removing mold indoors.
A 10% bleach solution is recommended on many different “black mold” removal websites.
A 5% white vinegar solution is also frequently cited as inhibiting “black mold” growth.

pageData.text: Important safety note: Vinegar and bleach should never be mixed together. When they are combined, they result in toxic gas.
In this investigation, you will determine the effectiveness of these common household cleaners in preventing the growth of R. stolonifera.

pageData.question: The black color of Rhizopus fungi comes from which of the following structures?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The black sporangia produce numerous multinucleate spores for asexual reproduction and it this characteristic that gives the genus Rhizopus fungi the name “black mold.”

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about Rhizopus reproduction is true?

options.text: Reproduction only takes place if two individuals meet within the fertile zone.
The rhizoid is the primary reproductive structure.
Sexual reproduction occurs when two hyphae of the same mating type fuse together.
The product of sexual reproduction is a sporangiophore.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The sporangium contains asexual spores (sporangiospores). Sexual reproduction in Rhizopus occurs when two hyphae of opposite mating types (+ and -) fuse to form a zygospore.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mycelium of fungi in the genus Rhizopus is composed of non-septate (undivided), multinucleate hyphae. Stolons are horizontal hyphae that form a group of rhizoids when they contact a solid substrate. Rhizoids penetrate the substrate to anchor the fungus. Sporangiophores extend above the rhizoids and terminate in a globose sporangium. The sporangium contains asexual spores, sporangiospores, and has an outer fertile zone and an inner sterile zone. The inner zone is called the columella and it aids in the release of the spores from the sporangium at maturity. Sexual reproduction in Rhizopus occurs when two hyphae of opposite mating types (+ and –) fuse to form a zygospore. After dormancy, the zygospore undergoes meiosis and germinates to form a germ sporangium. Sporangiospores from this sporangium form new mycelia.

img.alt: Figure 1: Magnified diagram of Rhizopus sporangia

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The mycelium of fungi in the genus Rhizopus is composed of non-septate (undivided), multinucleate hyphae. Stolons are horizontal hyphae that form a group of rhizoids when they contact a solid substrate. Rhizoids penetrate the substrate to anchor the fungus. Sporangiophores extend above the rhizoids and terminate in a globose sporangium. The sporangium contains asexual spores, sporangiospores, and has an outer fertile zone and an inner sterile zone. The inner zone is called the columella and it aids in the release of the spores from the sporangium at maturity. Sexual reproduction in Rhizopusoccurs when two hyphae of opposite mating types (+ and –) fuse to form a zygospore. After dormancy, the zygospore undergoes meiosis and germinates to form a germ sporangium. Sporangiospores from this sporangium form new mycelia.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, disinfect your work surface and prepare your disposal jar; obtain your cleaning solutions to test in activity 1; obtain your products to test in activity 2; and record your hypotheses. In activity 1, prepare your culture, and prepare and label the PDA plates. Then, inoculate each plate with R. stolonifera spores. Next, label the cups, and set up the cleaning solutions and control. Then, add the solutions to each designated inoculated plate, and allow the plates to absorb the solution. Incubate the plates at room temperature. Finally, observe the growth of R. stolonifera every 24 hours for a total of 72 hours.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, prepare your culture, and prepare and label the PDA plates. Then, inoculate each plate with R. stolonifera spores. Next, label the cups, and set up the food or product solutions. Then, add the solutions to each designated inoculated plate, and allow the plates to absorb the solution. Incubate the plates at room temperature. Finally, observe the growth of R. stolonifera every 24 hours for a total of 72 hours.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Refer to your instructions and video on safe practices in the microbiology laboratory before beginning this investigation.

Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Chlorine bleach can cause serious eye damage. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.

pageData.altText: warning symbol, toxic symbol, health hazard symbol
pageData.text: Vinegar and bleach should never be mixed. When they are combined, they result in toxic gas. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. After completing your work, disinfect and discard any used inoculating tools and unneeded cultures.

A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. When handling mold, it is very important to wear gloves. Mold can be an allergen. If you are allergic to mold, contact your instructor; you may need to wear a mask or perform an alternative investigation.

pageData.text: Read all instructions carefully before you start working.
Obtain all materials.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Always wear PPE when disinfecting.
Watch the following video on how to handle sterile inoculation tools.

In Activity 1, you will be testing vinegar, soap, baking soda, bleach, and a cleaning solution of your choice for their ability to inhibit the growth of R. stolonifera. What is your hypothesis? Research the merits of these common household cleaners and create a hypothesis. Record your research and hypothesis in the Lab Notebook. Record your predictions as to how much growth will be on the plates at each time interval in Data Table 1. You will collect data and make observations in this lab that will allow you to test your hypothesis.

In Activity 2, you will be testing four products or foods that are recommended to inhibit microbial growth. Collect your four products or foods. Research the merits of these common products/foods and create a hypothesis. Record your hypothesis in the Lab Notebook. Record your predictions as to how much growth will be on the plates at each time interval in Data Table 2. You will collect data and make observations in this lab that will allow you to test your hypothesis.

In Activity 1, you will inoculate PDA plates with R. stolonifera and treat each plate with a different dilute cleaning solution. You will then incubate the plates and observe fungal growth over 72 hours.

typeBefore.text: As a general rule, allow media and cultures that have been stored in the refrigerator to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature prior to inoculation.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Inoculating the PDA Plates (14 steps)

pageData.text: Read through the procedure for each activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clear the work area.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE (gloves, safety goggles, and lab apron or lab coat).

Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with surface disinfectant by applying the 10% bleach solution with a paper towel. Allow all treated surfaces to remain damp for approximately 2 minutes, and then wipe away any residue.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.

Retrieve the Rhizopus stolonifera culture and 6 PDA plates from storage. If the media and culture have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.

Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the outside of the bottom half of each dish with the date. Label each plate with one of the following labels: “baking soda”, “bleach”, “soap”, “vinegar”, “choice”, and “control”.
Use a sterile swab to obtain spores from the R. stolonifera culture. The spores may be white or black.

Lift the lid of the petri dish slightly. Do not remove the lid completely, and do not set it aside. Use the lid as a shield to protect the agar from contamination by airborne microbes. Inoculate the plate labeled “control” by gently pulling the swab back and forth across the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern.

Turn the plate approximately 90 degrees, and without dipping the swab back onto your R. stolonifer culture, pull the swab again over the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern. Try not to miss any of the agar surface.
Repeat Step 6 two more times until you have swabbed the entire surface of the agar four times. Place the swab in the disposal jar.
Let the plate sit right-side up with the lid on.
Repeat Steps 5–9 for the other 5 PDA plates.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Preparation and Application of Cleaning Solutions (10 steps)

pageData.text: Label 5 cups “control: boiled water”, “choice”, “baking soda”, “bleach”, and “soap” with the grease pencil. A cup for the vinegar is not required, as store-bought vinegar is already at the recommended strength for cleaning.
Use a sterile pipette to transfer approximately 9 mL of cooled boiled water in each cup. The line right under the bulb of the pipette is approximately 1 mL.
Prepare a ~10% baking soda solution. Add 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda to the cup labeled “baking soda”. Gently swirl until the baking soda is dissolved.
Prepare the ~10% bleach solution. Using a sterile pipet, add 1 mL bleach to the cup labeled “bleach”. Gently swirl to mix.
Prepare the soap solution. Add 1 drop of the soap to the cup labeled “soap”. Gently swirl to mix.
Prepare your household cleaning solution of your choice as directed on the container. Add 1 drop of this cleaning solution to the cup labeled, “cleaning solution”. Gently swirl to mix.
After you prepare each solution, complete the following steps:

text: Using a sterile pipet, place 1 mL of the solution on top of the agar of the inoculated plate labeled the same as solution you are applying.
Carefully rock the plate back forth to ensure the solution covers the entire surface of the plate.
Let the plate sit with the lid side up for 10–15 minutes, or until no liquid is visible.
When all liquid has been absorbed into the agar, invert the plate (place the plate lid-side down) and set it aside for incubation at room temperature.

pageData.text: Set up the control plate by performing Steps 7a–d. Dispose of the pipet in the trash.

Dispose of the prepared cleaning solutions. While wearing your PPE, one at a time, pour the solutions down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the solution. Repeat for each solution.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>
Important Safety Note: Vinegar and bleach should never be mixed. When they are combined, they result in toxic gas.
Incubate plates at room temperature, away from direct sunlight.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Incubation and Data Collection (7 steps)

pageData.text: After approximately 24 hours of incubation, examine your plates with the lids on. Do not remove the lids of the petri dishes during any observations, as this may result in contamination.
While keeping each petri dish closed, estimate the amount of growth covering the plate, and observe the color and texture Record your data in Data Table 3 in the Observation section.
Take photos of your plates in groups of 2 or 3. It may be necessary to use a dark piece of paper or dark surface to obtain a good picture.
After observations have been recorded, invert the plate (place the plate lid-side down) and set it aside for incubation.
After 48 hours, repeat Steps 2–4.
After 72 hours, repeat Steps 2–4.
After you have recorded your 72-hour data into Data Table 3, dispose of your plates by following the procedures outlined in the Disposal and Cleanup section.

In Activity 2, you will inoculate PDA plates with R. stolonifera and treat each plate with a different food or product solution of your choosing. You will then incubate the plates and observe fungal growth over 72 hours.

typeBefore.text: As a general rule, allow media and cultures that have been stored in the refrigerator to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature prior to inoculation.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Inoculating the PDA Plates (14 steps)

pageData.text: Read through the procedure for each activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clear the work area.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE (gloves, protective eyewear, and lab apron or lab coat).

Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with surface disinfectant by applying the 10% bleach solution with a paper towel, allowing all treated surfaces to remain damp for approximately 2 minutes, and then wiping away any remaining solution with a dry paper towel.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.

Retrieve the Rhizopus stolonifera culture and 4 PDA plates from storage. If the media and culture has been stored in the refrigerator, allow it to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the outside of the bottom half of each dish with the date. Label each plate with the name of the four foods or products you collected.
Use a sterile swab to obtain spores from the R. stolonifera culture. The spores may be white or black.

Lift the lid of the petri dish slightly. Do not remove the lid completely, and do not set it aside. Use the lid as a shield to protect the agar from contamination by airborne microbes. Inoculate the first plate by gently pulling the swab back and forth across the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern.

Turn the plate approximately 90 degrees, and, without dipping the swab back onto R. stolonifera (the culture), pull the swab again over the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern. Try not to miss any of the agar surface.
Repeat Step 10 two more times until you have swabbed the entire surface of the agar four times. Place the swab in the disposal jar.
Let the plate sit with the lid on and sitting right-side up.
Repeat Steps 6–10 for the other 3 PDA plates.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Preparation and Application of Products or Foods (4 steps)

pageData.text: Depending on which products or foods you choose, you may decide to place 1 mL directly on the plate. For example, if you choose to investigate mouthwash, you may place 1 mL directly on the plate. If you choose to investigate a food or household product that you think needs to be diluted, refer to Activity 1, Steps 3–7.
After you prepare each food or household product solution, you will complete the following steps:

text: Using a sterile pipet, place 1 mL of the solution on top of the agar of the inoculated plate labeled the same as solution you are applying.
Carefully rock the plate back forth to ensure the solution covers the entire surface of the plate.

pageData.text: Let the plate sit with the lid side up for 10–15 minutes, or until no liquid is visible.

text: 1. When all liquid has been absorbed into the agar invert the plate (place the lid plate-side down) and set it aside for incubation at room temperature.

pageData.text: Dispose of cleaning solutions. While wearing your PPE, one at a time, pour a solution down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the solution. Repeat for each solution.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>
Vinegar and bleach should never be mixed. When they are combined, they result in toxic gas.
Incubate plates at room temperature, away from direct sunlight.

typeBefore.title:
C
 Incubation and Data Collection (7 steps)

pageData.text: After approximately 24 hours of incubation, examine your plates with the lids on. Do not remove the lids of the petri dishes during any observations, as this may result in contamination.
While keeping each petri dish closed, estimate the amount of growth covering the plate, and observe the color and texture Record your data in Data Table 4.
Take photos of your plates in groups of 2 or 3. It may be necessary to use a dark piece of paper or dark surface to obtain a good picture.
After observations have been recorded, invert the plate (turn it upside-down) and set it aside for incubation.
After 48 hours, repeat Steps 2–4.
After 72 hours, repeat Steps 2–4.
After you have recorded your 72-hour data into Data Table 4, dispose of your plates by following the procedures outlined in the Disposal and Cleanup section.

To dispose of used inoculating tools (pipets, loops and/or swabs), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes, then pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running, and discard the loops in the garbage. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.

To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container (large enough to hold all the cultures) with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.

Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.

text: After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean with soap and water. Always wear your PPE during the disinfection and cleaning process.

Figure 2: A view of fungal growth from the top of a culture dish which shows black spores around the edge of the petri dish
pageData.content: Figure 2. Plate of R. stolonifera growth from above

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Culture plate looking at fungal growth from the bottom
pageData.content: Figure 3. Plate of R. stolonifera growth from below

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, disinfect your work surface and prepare your disposal jar; obtain your cleaning solutions to test in activity 1; obtain your products to test in activity 2; and record your hypotheses. In activity 1, prepare your culture, and prepare and label the PDA plates. Then, inoculate each plate with R. stolonifera spores. Next, label the cups, and set up the cleaning solutions and control. Then, add the solutions to each designated inoculated plate, and allow the plates to absorb the solution. Incubate the plates at room temperature. Finally, observe the growth of R. stolonifera every 24 hours for a total of 72 hours.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, prepare your culture, and prepare and label the PDA plates. Then, inoculate each plate with R. stolonifera spores. Next, label the cups, and set up the food or product solutions. Then, add the solutions to each designated inoculated plate, and allow the plates to absorb the solution. Incubate the plates at room temperature. Finally, observe the growth of R. stolonifera every 24 hours for a total of 72 hours.

data.title: Ascomycota
data.content: The largest phylum of Kingdom Fungi; its members produce ascospores and are also known as sac fungi

data.title: Basidiomycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members produce basidiospores; members include many edible and poisonous mushrooms,  shelf fungi, rusts, and smuts

data.title: Chytridiomycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members typically live in aquatic or moist habitats, have motile flagellated spores, and are either parasitic or saprophytic; members are informally known as chytrids

data.title: Columella
data.content: A non-reproductive structure that supports or holds the sporangium of some species of fungi

data.title: Fertile zone
data.content: The outer region of a sporangium that surrounds the columella

data.title: Glomeromycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members are soil fungi that reproduce asexually

data.title: Sporangiophore
data.content: A stalk or similar structure bearing a sporangium

data.title: Sporangiospore
data.content: An asexual spore produced by a sporangium and which gives rise to a new sporangium

data.title: Sporangium
data.content: A structure within which spores are produced; plural, sporangia

data.title: Stolon
data.content: A horizontal hypha that forms a group of rhizoids when in contact with a solid substrate

data.title: Zygomycota
data.content: The smallest phylum of Kingdom Fungi; its members are mostly terrestrial and commonly known as bread molds
